abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Cultural Heritage
            Project for Tunisia were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately unsatisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            substantial; Bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory
            and borrower performance was also moderately unsatisfactory.
            Some lessons learned includes: projects should be fully
            designed and costed before appraisal. Investment projects
            should not be allowed to go for Board approval without
            advanced preparation or completion of the final design
            studies and cost estimates for all components, in agreement
            with the relevant country authorities. Investment in
            cultural heritage is a complex process that requires a
            combination of lending instruments and technical support. As
            evidenced in similar operations worldwide, museum and art
            center projects are always difficult and require a
            preparation that is both time consuming and
            resource-intensive. Ownership and commitment to key reforms
            should play a central role in risk evaluation. Economic
            benefits can be very high for cultural heritage investments.
            Especially in the cultural heritage sector, even low cost
            investments that are strategically selected and positioned
            can have a decisive impact. Need for a longer-term sector engagement.

16498937.majtheme: Trade and integration,Financial and private sector development,Rule of law

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Cultural Heritage
            Project for Tunisia is to assist the Government in the
            sustainable management of the country's cultural
            heritage in order to develop cultural tourism and, in time,
            gain additional revenues, through: (i) enhancement of the
            legal framework, development of policies, and strengthening
            of cultural institutions capacity to enable efficient
            management of the country's cultural assets; (ii)
            development and marketing of cultural products, including
            promotion and communication programs; and (iii) improving
            infrastructure and management of a representative sample of
            six archaeological and historic sites to increase their
            appeal and tourism potential. A level two restructuring of
            the project, scheduled to close on December 31, 2011, is
            being requested to modify the description of some of the
            project sub-components and indicators in order to properly
            reflect the decisions made at the project mid-term review
            (2005) and implemented ever since.  These changes will be
            reflected in the project loan agreement and supplemental letter.

display_title.display_title:
Tunisia - Cultural Heritage
            Project : restructuring : Main report

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Cultural Heritage
            Project for Tunisia is to assist the Government in the
            sustainable management of the country's cultural
            heritage in order to develop cultural tourism and, in time,
            gain additional revenues, through: (i) enhancement of the
            legal framework, development of policies, and strengthening
            of cultural institutions capacity to enable efficient
            management of the country's cultural assets; (ii)
            development and marketing of cultural products, including
            promotion and communication programs; and (iii) improving
            infrastructure and management of a representative sample of
            six archaeological and historic sites to increase their
            appeal and tourism potential. The closing date for the
            project will be extended from June 30, 2011 until December
            31, 2011. In addition, a reallocation of funds among Project
            categories from 'goods' and 'consultant
            services', overestimated at the time of appraisal, to
            'works' will also be made. This will allow for
            completion of works on the main remaining sites. This will
            be the third extension of the project.
